awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Engineering Bimetallic Nanostructures as Peroxidase Mimics for Diagnostic Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
A strategy chemists often employ in sensor design is to use a chemical called a "catalyst", a substance that can bring about a chemical change. In the present project the desired change is the formation of colored products from uncolored chemicals for detection purposes.  The presence of the targeted chemical can then be detected by colorimetric assay which quantifies the intensity of the colored product.  While colorimetric technology is easy to use without lengthy training and with inexpensive equipment, the detection sensitivity of colorimetric assays can be less than optimum. In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Xiaohu Xia of Michigan Technological University is studying bimetallic nanostructures as the active component of chemical sensors for properties that result from their very small particle size and their chemical composition.  Their behavior mimics that of naturally-occurring peroxidases, a type of enzyme that is good at transforming biological disease markers into colored products but which suffers from low reactivity.  Investigation of the synthesis and fundamental catalytic behavior of the bimetallic nanoparticles are evaluated by their use in sensitive and reliable colorimetric assays for disease biomarkers. Broader impacts of the research result from the creation of simple and affordable sensor technologies which can greatly improve our standard of living through better disease biomarker detection.  Broader impacts are also made in education and outreach activities, which engage graduate and undergraduate students, especially women and minorities, in fundamental research.  The research is integrated into outreach activities for K-12 students from the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.   The well-defined nanocrystals, with striking shapes and uniform sizes, serve as vivid examples that are particularly appropriate for the K-12 level students to foster their interests and curiosities in modern nanoscience and nanotechnology.


In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Xiaohu Xia of Michigan Technological University is studying bimetallic nanostructures as the active component of chemical sensors for their ability to act as peroxidase mimics toward targeted disease marker molecules.  The research engineers the bimetallic nanoparticles in a unique Pd@M_nL core@shell structure, where M is composed of Pt, Ir, Rh, Ru, or Au and with the number of nanolayers (nL) equal to 1-10 atomic layers.  By carefully controlling the crystallographic plane and elemental composition of the surface, Dr. Xia is able to maximize the efficiency of the bimetallic particles for improved detection limits in colorimetric assays.  By coupling atomic-level electron microscopy imaging with theoretical simulations, this research addresses scientific questions of the structure-property relationships of bimetallic nanoparticle peroxidase mimics that are presently only poorly understood.  Broader impacts of the research result from improved sensor technology, since as alternatives to natural peroxidase, these highly efficient mimics are straightforwardly to use for in-vitro diagnostics of disease biomarkers.  Broader impacts are also made in education and outreach activities, which benefit in the engagement of graduate and undergraduate students, especially women and minorities, in fundamental research.  The research is integrated into outreach activities for K-12 students from the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.   The well-defined nanocrystals, with striking shapes and uniform sizes, serve as vivid examples that are particularly appropriate for the K-12 level students to foster their interests and curiosities in modern nanoscience and nanotechnology.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES

por.por_cntn:
To overcome the inherent drawbacks of natural peroxidases that are widely used as labels in in vitro diagnostic technologies, nanostructures with peroxidase-like catalytic activities (which are termed “peroxidase mimics”) have been actively developed over the past few decades. While a variety of peroxidase mimics have been reported, it is still challenging to substantially improve their catalytic efficiencies and gain mechanistic understanding. It should be emphasized that high catalytic efficiency is critical to ensure a high performance (e.g., low limit of detection) of peroxidase mimics-based diagnostics because catalysis is the driving force for producing detection signal.

In this project, we proposed to develop a class of highly efficient peroxidase mimics that are engineered by crafting nanostructures made of noble metals, including Pt, Ir, Rh, Ru, Pd, and Au. Our strategy for enhancing catalytic efficiency is to carefully engineer noble-metal nanostructures at the atomic precision, to gain insights into the structure-property relationship, and to understand experimental findings and guide further experiments with computational simulations. In addition to materials design and synthesis, we have applied the noble-metal nanostructures as peroxidase mimics to common diagnostic technologies, including lateral flow assay (LFA) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).

The most significant fundamental outcome of this project is that we have been able to design and synthesize highly efficient peroxidase mimics and been able to gain mechanistic understandings behind materials engineering. The catalytic efficiency in terms of catalytic constant (Kcat, defined as the maximum number of color products generated per second per enzyme or mimic) of most already reported peroxidase mimics with dimensions of 1-100 nm is generally limited to 104-105 s-1, only a few orders of magnitude more efficient than horseradish peroxidase (HRP) as a typical natural peroxidase (Kcat-HRP = 103 s-1). In this project, we were able to develop noble-metal peroxidase mimics with Kcat values as high as 106-107 s-1. Examples of our peroxidase mimics include Pt nanocubes, Au-Pt nanoparticles, Pd-Ir nanoparticles, Pd-Ru nanoparticles, Pd nanostructures, Ni-Pt nanoparticles, and Au-Ir nanoparticles. Notably, the Ni-Pt nanoparticles with a diameter <20 nm possess a Kcat of 4.5 × 107 s–1, which represents a record high catalytic efficiency at the time of our report. We have gained mechanistic understanding of catalytic efficiencies of the peroxidase mimics through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. With both experimental findings and theorical calculations, we have obtained in-depth understanding of structure-property relationships. For instance, we have investigated the role played by strain effect in determining the peroxidase-like catalytic activities using Pd nanostructures as a model system. In another study, we have demonstrated that the peroxidase-like catalytic activity of Pt nanostructures can be significantly improved by coupling Pt with Ni.

In technical aspect of the outcomes, we have substantially improved the sensitivities of lateral flow assay (LFA) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) using our noble-metal peroxidase mimics as labels. For example, we have demonstrated that the sensitivity of LFA can be improved by hundreds of times using Au-Pt or Au-Ir nanoparticles as alternatives to conventional Au nanoparticles. The sensitivity of ELISA can be significantly improved by replacing enzymes in conventional ELISA with our noble-metal peroxidase mimics. More details about technological advancement of diagnostic technologies using noble-metal peroxidase mimics can be found in our recently published review articles (e.g., J. Mater. Chem. B 2018, 6, 7102; ChemNanoMat, 2019, 5, 860; and Chem. Commun. 2020, 56, 14962).

This research project contributed to an improved understanding of peroxidase mimic development and technical advancement of in vitro diagnostic technologies. The project also provided training for undergraduate and graduate students as well as high school students in the STEM disciplines.


Last Modified: 04/28/2023
Modified by: Xiaohu Xia
